title: Before 2030, how many new AI labs will be leading labs within 2 years of their founding?
description: Since the release of [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT), an AI chatbot made by OpenAI and the [fastest-growing app in history](https://www.reuters.com/technology/chatgpt-sets-record-fastest-growing-user-base-analyst-note-2023-02-01/), new players have flocked to the AI scene—for example, Elon Musk’s [xAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XAI_(company)) and French upstart [Mistral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mistral_AI), [now a Microsoft partner](https://www.ft.com/content/cd6eb51a-3276-450f-87fd-97e8410db9eb). On top of this, AI labs have a history of splitting apart to form new labs. [Anthropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic) was founded by OpenAI employees; [Udio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Udio) was founded by Google DeepMind employees. Demis Hassabis, Google DeepMind CEO, has even mused about leaving and raising billions of dollars to start a new lab, reportedly on account of frustrations with corporate politics ([Victor, 2024](https://www.theinformation.com/articles/googles-demis-hassabis-chafes-under-new-ai-push)).
fine_print:
If Chatbot Arena is no longer maintained, or becomes obsolete because LLMs are no longer the frontier paradigm in AI, then Metaculus admins will find an alternative way to define “leading lab”.

 The Date is: 2025-01-28

Here are the relevant news articles:

**China's AI Talent Gap Expected to Reach 4 Million by 2030**
According to CCTV, the Chinese AI talent gap is expected to reach 4 million by 2030. The Chinese government has been actively promoting the AI industry over the past decade, and the number of users of generative AI products in China has reached 249 million, accounting for 17.7% of the total population. The industry report points out that the talent gap in AI will reach 4 million by 2030. DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup, has released a new AI model called DeepSeek R1, which has shocked the global AI industry. The company's founder, Liang Wenfeng, and his team have created two domestic AI products, which have shaken the global and US tech industry. DeepSeek has applied for a free app download on the Apple US App Store, ranking first in the free app download list in the US region, surpassing ChatGPT. AI talent is in short supply, and industry insiders believe that this is a golden age for AI talent. According to CCTV's financial report, the number of Chinese domestic video generation large models has shown an explosive growth trend since 2024. New job demands have emerged, such as AI content creators, AI director assistants, and AI script generation specialists. AI beauty engineer Cao Jun said, 'This position requires good aesthetic taste and aesthetic judgment.' 'Currently, I think this gap is still quite large, because people are not aware of the need for this position and the emergence of this job.' 'If it's self-media applications, AIGC talent demand is almost unlimited. Once you try AI, you'll find that it can realize your dreams that you've had for years. It's like adding a brush to a pen.' Beijing-based technology company product vice president Liao Qian said, 'AI beauty engineers, AI editors, they can produce AI big movies using our products. We believe that this job position has a shortage of at least tens of thousands.'

Publish date: January 28, 2025 08:25 AM
Source:[ETtoday新聞雲](https://www.ettoday.net/news/20250128/2900323.htm)

**Domestic Video Generation Large Model Experiences Explosive Growth, China's AI Talent Gap May Reach 4 Million by 2030**
The domestic video generation large model has experienced explosive growth since 2024, with new job demands emerging such as AI content creators, AI director assistants, and AI script generators. According to data, by December 2024, the user scale of generative artificial intelligence products in China reached 249 million, accounting for 17.7% of the total population. In 2024, the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security released 19 new occupations, including generative artificial intelligence system application personnel. Industry reports predict that by 2030, China's AI talent gap will reach 4 million. 'The rapid growth of the domestic video generation large model has created a huge demand for AI talent,' said a report. 'If we don't cultivate and introduce more AI talent, it will hinder the development of the industry.'

**AI Growth Outpaces Skills Acquisition in Australia, According to Google & Accenture**
Research from Google and Accenture suggests that Australians are increasingly using artificial intelligence, but there is a significant disparity between the number of employees who feel equipped to use AI and what C-suite executives perceive that number to be. Google's survey found that 49% of Australians used generative AI in the last year, up from 38% in 2023, but only 70% of employees feel prepared to make the most of AI at work. In contrast, 91% of C-suite leaders believe their employees are able to use the technology efficiently. Accenture's research also found that employees are concerned about inaccuracies, lack of resources, and integration struggles with AI. The country needs 312,000 additional tech workers by 2030 to meet demand, and Microsoft has committed to equipping one million people across Australia and New Zealand with essential AI skills by 2026. Matt Coates, technology lead for Accenture in Australia and New Zealand, said, 'Too many organisations view generative AI solely as a technological solution, rather than as a driving force to rethink talent strategies.'

**Anthropic CEO Predicts AI Models Will Surpass Humans in 2-3 Years**
Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, predicts that new AI models will appear in the next 2-3 years, which will be used by consumers and will assist people, but eventually become better than humans in almost everything. Amodei believes that AI will have both positive and negative consequences. In the short term, he suggests using workload comparisons. 'Even if a machine does 90% of your work, the remaining 10% becomes super-loaded. You spend all your time doing these 10%, but you do 10 times more from those 10% that you used to do, and you do 10 times more because the other 90% is used [by AI]'. Amodei previously suggested that artificial superintelligence could become possible in 2026 or 2027. Other industry leaders, such as Sam Altman, CEO of Open AI, and Elon Musk, one of the co-founders of the company, believe that AI can surpass humans as early as 2025. Demis Hassabis, executive director of Google DeepMind, and Yann LeCun, chief scientific officer of Meta and Turing Award winner, are more conservative in their views, suggesting that artificial superintelligence may be created within the next decade.

**How AI is Helping Entrepreneurs**
A study by Digital Enterprise Show predicts that by 2025, 10% of data produced and 30% of marketing messages from major brands will be generated by AI. 98% of company leaders believe that AI will transform their strategies. However, 85 million jobs are at risk of being replaced. Experts like Javier Rodríguez Zapatero, president of Digitalent Group, see AI as a 'revolution that will change humanity after the discovery of fire'. Others, like Mark Kavelaars, cofounder of Swanlaab Venture Factory, see it as a 'moment of great change' that reminds him of the first time he sat in front of a PC 40 years ago. Companies like Lixsa.ai are helping small and medium-sized businesses to give a qualitative leap and gain a competitive advantage by using AI to optimize and automate key customer service processes. According to Javier González Báez, director of innovation at Acciona, 'small and medium-sized businesses have to do it now because it may be too late next year'. 'The AI will transform almost all areas within organizations, allowing them to increase productivity by solving complex problems quickly and simply, and simplifying processes that are currently complicated and time-consuming', says Martín Díaz Morquio, co-founder of Lixsa.ai. However, not everyone is optimistic, and Yolanda Díaz Villarrubia, founder of Idea B3Hub s, believes that those who do not integrate AI into their culture and processes will be left behind. 'The change has to be transversal and permeate the entire organization, managing the use of AI in a smart way, knowing when to automate tasks or not', she says. 'We have to avoid the risk of creating biases in the design of algorithms, like Amazon's, which always recommended men over women for a job', warns Cristina Carrascosa, cofounder of ATH21. New business opportunities are emerging, such as ZeroError, a platform that uses AI to detect anomalies in data. According to Maria José Marti, CEO and founder of ZeroError, 'we couldn't have existed 10 years ago because the technology didn't exist'. 'Thanks to AI combined with expertise in data analysis, we can solve real problems in just a few weeks', she says.

**The Future Of Work In The Age Of Artificial Intelligence -By Phebe Ejinkeonye-Christian**
A recent report by McKinsey Global Institute suggests that by 2030, over 375 million workers may need to switch jobs due to advancements in AI. Rather than fearing AI, we must adapt and develop skills that complement its strengths with our uniquely human skills. AI is designed to augment human abilities, but when we fail to upskill and align with its operations, it can easily outperform and replace us. To thrive in the age of AI, workers and business owners must focus on upskilling and reskilling, honing skills such as creativity, empathy, critical thinking, strategic planning, and innovation. Continuous learning and personal development are no longer optional but necessary for career longevity. Collaboration with AI rather than competition is the key to survival. By learning to work with AI tools, developing strong analytical skills, and focusing on human-centric skills, individuals can remain indispensable in their industries and create opportunities in the workforce. The future of work in the age of AI is not about job loss; it is about job transformation. By proactively developing skills that complement AI, workers can stay ahead in the workforce and drive innovation.

Bill Gates believes that everyone should read his favorite book on artificial intelligence, which predicts that AI will change the shape of most jobs in almost every industry within the next five years, according to a report by CBS News. The book, 'The Next Wave: Technology and Power and the Greatest Challenge of the 21st Century', was written by Mustafa Suleyman, a pioneer in AI and the founder of the research lab DeepMind, which was sold to Google in 2014 and is now the executive director of Microsoft AI. Gates wrote on his blog last month: 'It is the book that I recommend more than any other book on AI - to heads of state, business leaders, and anyone else who asks - because it provides something rare: a clear vision of both the extraordinary opportunities and the real risks of the future.' In the book, Suleyman predicts that the rapid development of AI will change the way almost every industry works. He cites a 2023 study by McKinsey, which estimated that nearly half of all 'work activities' will become automated by 2030. Suleyman writes that the consequences of AI will be 'extremely destabilizing' for hundreds of millions of people who will need, at the very least, to be retrained and transition to new types of work. According to McKinsey, more than 400 million workers worldwide may need to transition to new jobs or roles. Suleyman says that AI will help workers become more efficient, as it already has in some cases, but only initially. He explains that 'these tools will only augment human intelligence temporarily. They will make us more intelligent and efficient for a while, and they will open up huge amounts of economic growth, but they will replace labor essentially.' How to prepare for the impact of AI on the workforce? Suleyman notes that from 'physical manufacturing' to 'cognitive work', the AI revolution will touch almost every industry. In the end, there will be 'few areas' where humans will be able to surpass machines. AI will quickly surpass human workers in office tasks such as administration, customer service, and content creation, according to Suleyman. He points out that the increase in inputs is likely to lead to a reality where employers will create millions of new jobs in response to economic growth. However, Suleyman notes that all this work will not go to humans: employers will choose 'very low-cost incentives' whenever possible. Some jobs are harder for AI to replicate. These include skilled trades such as plumbers and electricians, as well as office roles that rely heavily on social skills, critical thinking, and creativity. However, it is likely that everyone will need to upgrade their skills - and learn how to integrate this type of technology into their current jobs, as AI services spread across all industries over the coming years. Suleyman writes that many others will need to transition to entirely new jobs. This transformation is already underway. In 2023, a survey by EY found that 41% of American companies surveyed were implementing plans to train employees to work with AI products. According to a survey by Slack Workforce Lab in March 2024 of over 10,000 professionals, the key AI skills - such as rapid prototyping, machine learning, and data literacy - are a major factor in hiring for nearly 70% of employers. The massive challenge posed by AI to jobs. Some experts suggest that the economic benefits of AI will create enough new jobs to outweigh those lost. AI will create 78 million more jobs than it replaces by 2030, and the future of work will revolve around collaboration between humans and machines, according to the World Economic Forum's Future of Jobs 2025 report earlier this year. Even the optimists about AI agree that the massive changes in how people work are likely to lead to a period of dramatic transformation. In his book, Suleyman predicts that the new jobs enabled by AI developments will not come soon enough to save large parts of the global workforce. Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, said in a discussion with MIT President Sally Kornbluth in May 2024 that AI 'will kill a lot of current jobs, (and) there will be categories of jobs that will disappear completely.' 'Innovative treatments' and 'innovative solutions' and other benefits. Suleyman and Gates remain generally optimistic about the ability of AI to change people's lives for the better. Gates wrote last month that if workers and leaders prepare for massive changes, everyone should be able to enjoy the benefits of 'innovative treatments for deadly diseases, innovative solutions to climate change, and high-quality education for all.' To achieve this better scenario, humans need to adopt AI by learning how to work with new technologies while implementing them in their daily lives and careers. This can start by exploring free online AI services such as 'Chat GPT' or other large language models that use AI. More advanced options include taking online courses to learn AI skills such as rapid prototyping. Suleyman emphasizes that 'this is a massive challenge that will determine, without exaggeration, the quality and nature of life in this century and the next.'

**Artificial Intelligence to Create 170 Million New Jobs by 2030, Report Says**
The World Economic Forum (WEF) has recently released the Future of Jobs Report 2025, which extensively analyzes global trends in the labor market and predicts their impact on jobs, skills, and worker transformation strategies in 2025-2030. A significant part of the report is dedicated to the role of artificial intelligence in the world's workforce. According to the report, the most significant trends in the labor market in 2025-2030 are: technological advancements, economic turbulence, green energy, lack of security, and an aging population. The report is based on surveys of over 1,000 employers representing over 14 million workers in 22 industry clusters and 55 economies worldwide. The authors of the report also collaborated with platforms such as Coursera, LinkedIn, and Indeed to supplement the survey results with real data on employment trends. The report predicts that by 2030, there will be approximately 170 million new jobs created, with AI playing a key role. However, 92 million roles will be replaced, resulting in a net increase of 78 million jobs. Technological changes remain the main driver of changes, with the expansion of digital access creating and displacing more jobs than any other macro-trend. AI and information technologies can provide 11 million new jobs, despite the expected displacement of 9 million. Meanwhile, robotics and autonomous systems will become the largest reducer, reducing the number of jobs by 5 million. For example, since the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022, investment in AI has increased by almost eight times, accompanied by increased funding for server infrastructure and energy systems to support AI systems. Although information technologies are leaders in the implementation of AI, the real sector of the economy, including industries such as construction and manufacturing, lags behind. Generative AI, in particular, technologies based on natural language processing (NLP), most significantly change work processes in finance, healthcare, education, retail, and the IT sector. It is expected that by 2030, the share of tasks performed exclusively by humans will decrease from 47% to 33%, and the share of automated tasks will increase from 22% to 33%. The report notes a change in the paradigm of future human-machine work. Interaction between humans, machines, and algorithms changes work roles in various fields. It is expected that automation will lead to changes in the way people work, and the proportional share of tasks performed exclusively or primarily by humans will decrease as technologies become more universal.

**AI Startups Dominate New Unicorns in 2024, But Face Fundraising Challenges**
According to CB Insights, 44% of the 72 new unicorns in 2024 are AI startups, a record high. This represents a growth of over 7x since 2015, when only 6% of new unicorns were AI startups. These AI startups are also achieving unicorn status at a record pace, with a median of two years, compared to nine years for non-AI startups. The growth of AI startups can be attributed to their ability to operate with smaller and more agile teams. For example, World Labs, with 18 employees, and Skild AI, with 19 employees, both founded in 2023, have already been valued at over $1 billion. The analysis suggests that AI startups are able to automate certain functions and scale faster with fewer employees than non-AI startups. Additionally, the hype surrounding AI technology is attracting investors' attention earlier. Some of the smallest AI teams among the new unicorns include: World Labs (18 employees, founded in 2024, valued at $1 billion), Skild AI (19 employees, founded in 2023, valued at $1.5 billion), Sakana AI (34 employees, founded in 2023, valued at $1.5 billion), Cognition AI (49 employees, founded in 2023, valued at $2 billion), and Poolside (75 employees, founded in 2023, valued at $3 billion). These startups are focused on emerging areas of opportunity in AI, such as intelligent robotics and embedded AI, and AI agents and copilots for coding. However, the report also notes that unicorns are facing challenges in fundraising, with over a third of unicorns not receiving new investments since 2021. If these companies tried to raise money now, their valuation would likely be lower due to the current economic climate, which could cause their value to drop below $1 billion, making them no longer considered unicorns.
